DEAR DIARY:

The young couple browsing at the garage sale seemed taken with a cut-glass vase. The man admired its graceful lines and delicate pattern; the woman said she had seen it for three times the price at Fortunoff's.
''We'll put it on the coffee table,'' he said.
So they carelessly left it unguarded while they examined an ice bucket. Immediately, the customer to their right snatched up the vase, paid the homeowner and left.
''O.K., Mom,'' the young woman asked. ''What do you want us to sell next?''
BATHROOM HUMOR
A most peculiar guy
In the adjacent stall:
''I love you, too. Goodbye'''
Concludes his cellphone call.
Now, doesn't it deflate your
Idea of the romantic
That even calls of nature
Require Bell Atlantic?
BOB McKENTY
At a recent concert of the Princeton Chamber Symphony in Richardson Auditorium I was seated behind a family of six, including the infant.
A voice a few rows behind me tsk-tsked in disapproval: ''A baby! At a concert!''
When the appearance of the conductor, Mark Laycock, brought a thunder of applause, the baby decided to add her own special sounds.
From behind me came the voice triumphantly, ''Bye bye,'' as the father whisked away the infant.
One of the orchestral selections was Arvo Part's Symphony No. 2, a work devoid of whistleable tunes.
At that point, the voice a few rows back again reacted with disapproval. ''Bring back the baby,'' he said.
MARY ELIZABETH HARTZ
My mother bought us the board game ''Who Wants to Be a Millionaire'' and we were playing it on Mother's Day.
When it was my daughter's turn to be the host, she started putting question cards back in the wrong stacks. Naturally, I corrected her.
''Mom,'' she said with a groan, ''do you think Regis's mother does that?''
DEBRA GALANT
Overheard at a restaurant in West Orange on Mother's Day was this exchange between a father and his 4-year-old daughter:
Father: ''Do you know whose special day this is?''
Daughter: ''It's Mommy and Daddy's special day.''
Father: ''Why is that?''
Daughter: ''Mommy's because she doesn't have to cook, and Daddy's because he doesn't have to eat Mommy's cooking.''
MARILYN VASEN
ATTRACTED TO THE LIGHT (VERSE)
M is for the million times you bugged me
O is for the one time you did better
T is for the times you sometimes mugged me
H is for the hole in my new sweater.
Put them all together they spell Moth
My little revered insect of the cloth.
EDMUND CONTI
When I visited the play area at Burke's Park in Parlin last winter, with my three grandchildren, 2-year-old Elizabeth slipped on the icy sand and landed on her backside.
Recently, on our first visit to the park since that slip, Elizabeth exclaimed, ''Where did the ice go?''
JAMES CARNEY
